title: Media of Things
acknowledgements: Tom Bartindale, Jasmine Cox, Ian Strafford, Dan Hett, Chris Northwood, Derek Brown.

blocks.title: Sensing in Productions
blocks.subtitle: Constructing immersive and adaptive media experiences requires a detailed understanding of captured media assets. A production studio with hundreds of sensors and devices, tracking the chef’s every move and measuring each ingredient.
paragraphs: This project required a scalable and highly reliable system to capture a wealth of information about a real production. In order to achieve this our team set about constructing a data capture system to store footage from the cameras and sensors in real-time. The system could analyse the data using machine learning, computer vision and AI in near real-time providing labelled output to professional editors at the BBC. We contracted the set in house making it portable and setup within 2-3 hours.

paragraphs.text: We developed bespoke 3D renders of the kitchen island before construction. This allowed us to design our portable kitchen, check scale and usable workspace for the chef before being on set.

We had an incredible array of sensing technologies within the set and kitchen island. RFID identified and located objects across the workbench, utensils sensors detected what was in use and what utensils were being used for and water flow meters measured amounts dispensed from the tap.

title: Escape the Future
acknowledgements: Daniel Lambton-Howard, James Hodge, Shaun Hazeldine, Aarathi Krishnan, Yann Le Floch

blocks.title: Immersive Experience
blocks.subtitle: Typically, organisational strategy is expressed in verbose documents that are distributed physically and digitally. In 2019 the largest humanitarian organisation, the International Federation of the Red Cross approached us to explore new ways of communicating policy and strategy to its delegates.
paragraphs: We present “Escape to the Future”, a digitally immersive escape room game for humanitarian strategy. Teams were teleported into the 5 key thematic areas, to enact 7 global transformations conveying topics on health, crisis and disasters, migration and identity, values and climate change.

paragraphs.text: Delegates were immersed in 360 degree projections with surround sound and given 30 minutes to complete challenges to help prevent the IFRC from falling into irrelevance.

Each challenge comprised of clues, puzzles and physical artefacts that needed to be solved through strong team communication. Implicit and explicit messaging allowed delegates to take control of their own destiny and make decisions that affected the future of the IFRC.  Over the course of the General Assembly 311 delegates from 67 national societies.

title: Expressive Things
sub_title: A new way to interact and control devices in the home
acknowledgements: Tom Bartindale, Jasmine Cox, Ian Strafford, Dan Hett, Chris Northwood, Derek Brown.

blocks.title: Meaningful Control
blocks.subtitle: This project created a novel mechanism to control devices and interact with a smart home. Using a wrist-worn sensor to track hand gestures used alongside devices like Google Homes and existing switches and remotes.
paragraphs: We sought to gain greater insight into the currently passive interactions in the home. Constructing a mechanism to track smart home device events, composing them into interactions. We saw an opportunity to develop more meaningful control in the home by exploiting the most favourable aspects of each (voice, gestural and physical). For example, combining a traditional lightswitch interaction with gestural control our system allows us to control the colour or brightness of a bulb by rolling of the wrist.

title: Hawk-Eye EDGE-SENSE
acknowledgements: Tom Bartindale, Jasmine Cox, Ian Strafford, Dan Hett, Chris Northwood, Derek Brown.

blocks.title: Clearing up the signal
blocks.subtitle: The Hawk-Eye EDGE-SENSE integrated an sensor embedded within cricket bats to enable professional level snick detection for umpires in the amateur game. Real-time sensor data streaming and playback for review.
paragraphs: We embedded an OpenMovement WAX9 sensor on the back of the bat connected to an iPad positioned near the umpire. The raw signal data is streamed over Bluetooth the the iPad when required by the umpire they can review the incident in slow motion using the iPad camera along side the synchronised sensor data from the bat. This data could also be integrated into professional broadcasts as it is sent to Hawk-Eye’s Smart production system.

title: OpenMovement AxLE
acknowledgements: Tom Bartindale, Jasmine Cox, Ian Strafford, Dan Hett, Chris Northwood, Derek Brown.

blocks.title: Open data collection
blocks.subtitle: The OpenMovement AxLE wrist-worn activity tracker adopts a new approach to data collection. Its long lasting battery life and open data formats provide research institutions and organisations
paragraphs: We developed a wrist-worn sensor and data collection platform using NRFUart hardware stack and Bluetooth Low Energy for wireless communication. This is an Open-Source project with the hardware designs, firmware and communication libraries all freely available and in continued development. The sensor tracks general activity data (steps, moments of inertia etc.), displays activity data to the user on the screen and provides for programatic interventions with the ability to vibrate and flash the device over bluetooth.

title: Think Active
sub_title: Activity Tracking Solution for Schools and Foundations

hero2.alt_text: Think Active integrates into childrens activity programmes

acknowledgements: Andy Foster, David Chatting, Rob Anderson

blocks.title: Be Active. Think Active.
blocks.subtitle: Think Active provides a fun and interactive means for children to learn more about their activity levels. We put children’s health first, improving data literacy in a safe and secure environment.
paragraphs: Think Active uses the latest in wireless technologies with Bluetooth Low Energy to sync data from OpenMovement AxLE activity trackers to the ActiveHub and is synced up to the Think Active servers for analysis. Teachers and Community Foundations can then monitor the effectiveness of their interventions. The Think Active Class Kit provides unparalleled insights into children’s health and wellbeing 24 hours a day, whilst providing a set of fun interactive challenges and data literacy materials for schools.

title: App Movement
acknowledgements: Tom Bartindale, Jasmine Cox, Ian Strafford, Dan Hett, Chris Northwood, Derek Brown.

blocks.title: Led by the Community
blocks.subtitle: Providing a space for groups and communities to come together around a concept for an application is the foundation of App Movment.
